channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Assassinations of Hezbollah and Hamas Leaders Stir Fears of Wider War
item.description: Hezbollah confirmed that one of its senior commanders, Fuad Shukr, had been killed in an Israeli strike on Beirut, and Hamas accused Israel of killing its political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, while he was in Tehran for the inauguration of Iran’s new president.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times

item.title: Unrest at Israeli Army Bases Highlights Battle for Country’s Soul
item.description: After Israeli soldiers were detained on suspicion of abusing a Palestinian, riots broke out that symbolize a wider struggle over Israel’s future that has divided the country.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Right-wing protesters demonstrate against the arrest of Israeli soldiers at Beit Lid military base, Israel.

item.title: More Ukrainians Appear Open to a Peace Deal
item.description: Most Ukrainians still oppose ceding any territory to Russia. But polls and recent remarks by the country’s leaders highlight a palpable shift in the conversation around peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Predchenko, right, and her mother, Kateryna Predchenko, looking at the makeshift memorial for fallen soldiers at Maidan Square in Kyiv last week.

item.title: Drone Strike in Sudan Targets Army Leader in Failed Assassination Attempt, Military Says
item.description: For 15 months, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan has been leading a war for control of the country against his rival, Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, the head of the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, center, during a graduation ceremony in Gebeit near Port Sudan on Wednesday.

item.title: Election Results Presented by Venezuela’s Opposition Suggest Maduro Lost Decisively
item.description: The Times analyzed partial voting tallies collected by the opposition. They cast further doubt on Nicolás Maduro’s declared victory.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ethan Singer
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waited outside a polling station for the announcement of results in the election on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Ismail Haniyeh, a Top Hamas Leader, Is Dead at 62
item.description: Mr. Haniyeh, the Palestinian militant group’s exiled political chief, managed high-stakes negotiations, including the ongoing cease-fire talks to end the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of professors gathered in front of the University of Tehran to protest the assassination of Mr. Haniyeh on Wednesday.

item.title: Guinea Court Finds Former President Guilty of Stadium Massacre and Rapes
item.description: The West African nation’s former leader and some of his top aides were found guilty of crimes against humanity for mass murder and rapes committed during and after a pro-democracy protest in 2009.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Abdourahmane Diallo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Ahmed Ouoba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Guinea’s former president, Capt. Moussa Dadis Camara, at a news conference in 2015.

item.title: Pro-Democracy Organization Denounces Venezuela’s Election
item.description: The Carter Center, a leading pro-democracy organization, says Venezuela’s election violated the country’s own laws and was undemocratic.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to vote on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Venezuela’s Election Was Deeply Flawed. Here’s How.
item.description: From voter intimidation to refusing to provide paper tallies to verify the result claimed by the government, the election was riddled with problems.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poll workers during the election on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Thai Women Use Boxing to Punch Their Way Out of Poverty
item.description: Boxing is a national passion in Thailand, offering a path to the Olympics and lucrative careers in a country with one of the world’s widest income divides.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thananya Somnuek, a member of Thailand’s Olympic boxing squad, trained in Bangkok in June. Boxing is practically a national sport in Thailand.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Hezbollah Commander in Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: The strike was in retaliation for a deadly rocket attack this weekend in the Golan Heights. At least three civilians were killed and 74 others wounded on Tuesday, Lebanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Farnaz Fassihi and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Hussein Malla/Associated Press
item.media:description: A destroyed building in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, after an Israeli strike on Tuesday. At least one person was killed.

item.title: Paris Olympics: Why Gymnast Kaylia Nemour Is Competing for Algeria, Not France
item.description: A bitter fight with the French gymnastics federation threatened the Olympic hopes of Kaylia Nemour. Dual nationality offered a way out.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle and James Hill
item.media:description: Kaylia Nemour, with hands on hips, at a gym in Avoine, western France. She is a medal favorite in the uneven bars.

item.title: Disinformation Fed Far-Right Riot in England After Deadly Stabbing
item.description: More than 50 police were injured in an outbreak of violence driven by false reports that the suspect in the stabbing attack on a children’s dance class was a migrant.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Getty Images/Getty Images
item.media:description: Riot police officers holding back protesters in Southport, England, on Tuesday.

item.title: War Gives Palestinian Olympians a Wider Role: Athlete-Diplomats
item.description: The Israel-Hamas war has given the eight Palestinians competing in Paris Olympics a higher profile than usual.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: The boxer Wasim Abusal competed with a Palestinian flag on his top.

item.title: Iran and Hamas Blame Israel for Killing of Ismail Haniyeh, and Vow Revenge
item.description: The deadly strike on Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran threatened to further inflame the region and derail negotiations aimed at reaching a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group in Tehran on Wednesday carried Palestinian flags and chanted death to Israel in protest of the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a Hamas leader.

item.title: Photos: Katie Ledecky Wins Gold in 1,500-Meter Freestyle, Lapping Competition Again
item.description: Katie Ledecky comfortably won the 1,500-meter freestyle, beating her winning time from the Tokyo Games by more than seven seconds.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Chang W. Lee and James Hill
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Two Al Jazeera Journalists Were Killed in an Israeli Strike on Gaza
item.description: A reporter and a cameraman were working from or near the house of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political chief who was assassinated on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ayman Al Hassi/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinians inspect a vehicle where Al Jazeera TV said its reporter Ismail al-Ghoul and cameraman Ramy El Rify were killed in an Israeli strike, in Gaza City July 31, 2024.

item.title: Iran’s Leader Orders Attack on Israel for Haniyeh Killing, Officials Say
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered retaliation after a humiliating security failure, as Iran once again balances showing strength against the risk of escalation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader who was assassinated in Iran on Wednesday, at a square in Tehran.

item.title: How Henrik Christiansen Made Chocolate Muffins a Hit at the Olympics
item.description: On a quest to fuel himself with thousands of calories a day, the Olympic swimmer Henrik Christiansen found an unexpected delight and shared it with the world.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Henrik Christiansen
item.media:description: The muffins on offer inside the cafeteria at the Olympic Village, in Saint-Denis.

item.title: Robot Captures Pictures of the Dotson Ice Shelf in Antarctica
item.description: The new images of the melting underside of an ice shelf could help scientists better forecast how the continent is contributing to rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: ‘20th Hijacker’ Is Denied Transfer From Federal Supermax to French Prison
item.description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person to be convicted in connection with the 9/11 attacks, had requested to serve the rest of his life sentence in his native country instead of a prison in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The supermax prison in Florence, Colo., where Zacarias Moussaoui is serving his life sentence.

item.title: How Will a Hamas Leader’s Killing Affect Gaza Cease-Fire Talks?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was assassinated in Iran, was a key figure in Hamas’s cease-fire negotiations with Israel and his assassination makes the prospects for a deal even more unclear.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis in Tel Aviv marked nine months in July since the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas.

item.title: After Haniyeh’s Death, Who Are Hamas’s Most Prominent Leaders?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was killed in Iran, was among the most senior members of Hamas’s leadership. Here is a look at others.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, head of the political bureau of Hamas, delivering a speech in 2023 in Gaza City.

item.title: Alex Yee overcomes currents, heat and a big deficit to pull of a dramatic comeback.
item.description: Alex Yee overcame a big deficit to pull off a dramatic comeback to win the men’s race.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Strikes in Iran and Lebanon Raise Risk of Escalation, but All-Out War Is Not Inevitable
item.description: The scale of the reaction from Iran and its regional proxies to the attacks on two of Israel’s largest foes could determine whether the low-level regional battle tips into a full-scale conflict.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and Hezbollah supporters carrying the coffins of Amira, 6, and her brother Hassan Fadlallah, 10, who were killed in an Israeli airstrike in Dahiyeh, a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Iceland Warns of Volcanic Eruption ‘In the Coming Days’
item.description: The Icelandic Meteorological Office has warned of an eruption “in the coming days.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: John Moore/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Sundhnukur volcano erupting on the Reykjanes Peninsula near Grindavik, Iceland, in June. The volcano, which has erupted five times since December, has forced the evacuation of the fishing village of Grindavik as well as the nearby Blue Lagoon geothermal spa.

item.title: Haniyeh’s Death Will Shake but Not Destroy Hamas, Analysts Say
item.description: Hamas will need to scramble to replace Ismail Haniyeh following his killing in Tehran, analysts say, but the group has recovered from past assassinations of its political and military leaders.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, center, in Gaza City in 2012. Mr. Haniyeh was one of Hamas’s most recognizable faces worldwide.

item.title: India’s Deadly Landslides, Explained
item.description: The death toll has steadily risen in Kerala state after heavy rain sent huge mudslides through a scenic area known as a tourist destination.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Pragati K.B. and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Idrees Mohammed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tea plantation workers heading to a relief camp after landslides in Kerala, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: Will the Assassination of a Hamas Leader Escalate the Risk of a Wider War?
item.description: Qatar and Egypt, the main mediators in talks to end the Gaza war, have warned that new assassinations risk plunging the region even deeper into chaos.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professors gather in front of the University of Tehran on Wednesday to protest the assassination of the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: Huw Edwards Pleads Guilty to Accessing Indecent Images of Children
item.description: Huw Edwards, who was one of Britain’s top television anchors, admitted to offenses in a London court on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Hollie Adams/Reuters
item.media:description: Huw Edwards, center, outside a London court on Wednesday.

item.title: Cruise Ship Ducks Are Traveling the World as Part of a Scavenger Hunt
item.description: Scavenger hunts for rubber ducks hidden by cruise passengers have spawned a duck-loving community of “quackers.”
item.dc:creator: Sara Ruberg
item.media:credit: Eve Chen/USA Today Network
item.media:description: Cruising duck enthusiasts, sometimes known as “quackers,” have been leaving rubber ducks on ships for other passengers to find.

item.title: As Republicans Attack Harris on Immigration, Here’s What Her Record Shows
item.description: Republicans blame Vice President Kamala Harris for the surge of migrants into the United States over the past several years. But a review of her involvement shows a more nuanced record.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris during a 2021 visit to El Paso, Texas, near the border with Mexico. She had previously resisted visiting the area, despite being tasked with a migration-related portfolio.

item.title: Trump Says Venezuela Sends Criminals to the U.S. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The former president says Venezuela’s crime rate has plunged because it is expelling criminals. But there is little evidence supporting the claim.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valencia
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelan migrants waiting in line last year to cross into the United States after receiving an asylum hearing in Juarez, Mexico.

item.title: Iran Has Accused Israel of Assassinations on Its Soil Before
item.description: Iran has blamed Israel for a series of targeted killings carried out within its borders.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran accused Israel of killing Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, a scientist described as a leading figure in its nuclear weapons program, in 2020.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The killing of a top Hamas leader in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Arif Hudaverdi Yaman/Anadolu, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh led Hamas’s political operations from exile in Qatar.

item.title: Traveling to China? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: China has been rolling out new visa-free programs and promising to make travel easier for foreigners. But challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Vincent Thian/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tourists near Shichahai Lake in Beijing this month. China has been taking unusual steps to attract visitors from overseas.

item.title: Why Chinese Propaganda Loves Foreign Travel Influencers
item.description: Videos by influencers documenting their trips have been widely promoted on Chinese media — if they tell a certain story.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: What We Know About the Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh
item.description: The top Hamas leader, who was central to the group’s high-stakes negotiations and diplomacy, was killed in Iran’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader, in Tehran in March.

item.title: After Olympic Triathlons in Seine, Leaders Hail Dual Wins for France
item.description: Years of digging pipes and cisterns, and more than $1 billion, were required to make the Seine River clean enough to host the races. Two French athletes won medals.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The men’s triathlon took place Wednesday morning after being delayed by a day.

item.title: Their Parents Fled War. Now South Sudan’s Young Team Is in the Olympics.
item.description: War, famine and floods have beleaguered the world’s youngest nation. The arrival of its men’s basketball team at the Paris Olympics is set to offer a modicum of hope.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Guillem Sartorio for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bright Stars are currently representing Africa in the Olympic men’s basketball tournament.

item.title: Not Even Anthony Edwards Can Beat an Olympic Table Tennis Player
item.description: An N.B.A. star’s trash talk was good-natured but typical, elite players said. They say they play along with it … to a point.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Amy Wang of United States during a match on Monday.

item.title: At 17, She’s Already Conquered Some of the World’s Big Swims
item.description: While attention has been on the Paris Olympics, Maya Merhige, a high school senior, swam from England to France, completing the triple crown in open-water swimming.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sophie Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 17-year-old swimmer Maya Merhige on the banks of the River Thames in London this month.

item.title: Israel Struck Beirut as ‘Axis of Resistance’ Leaders Attended Iran Inauguration
item.description: Iranian officials condemned the attack and warned that Hezbollah and Lebanon had the right to retaliate against Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iran’s new president Masoud Pezeshkian was sworn in on Tuesday in an inauguration ceremony in Tehran.

item.title: Antidoping Agency Acknowledges Concern Over Use of Tainted Food as Excuse
item.description: After a spate of positive tests for performance-enhancing drugs by athletes, the World Anti-Doping Agency is investigating why China and other countries are citing contaminated food as an explanation.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Joel Marklund
item.media:description: Witold Banka, the president of the World Anti-Doping Agency. The disclosures came at a time when the agency and the entire global antidoping system are under intensifying scrutiny.

item.title: After Dramatic Surrender, Son of El Chapo Pleads Not Guilty to Drug Charges
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán López gave himself up to U.S. authorities last week along with a former associate of his father’s.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Robert Chiarito
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: The plane believed to have carried Ismael Zambada García and Joaquín Guzmán López to El Paso last week.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Targets a Hezbollah Commander
item.description: Plus, deadly street clashes in Venezuela and the Booker Prize longlist
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: The site of an explosion in Beirut’s southern suburbs.

item.title: How Authoritarian Governments Rig Elections to Stay in Power
item.description: Nicolás Maduro was declared the winner of Venezuela’s presidential election despite widespread irregularities. Here are some tools autocrats like Mr. Maduro use to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a militia loyal to President Nicolás Maduro’s government at the entrance of a voting center in a neighborhood where the opposition lacked observers in Venezuela’s capital, Caracas.

item.title: Who Is Fuad Shukr, Target of the Israeli Strike on Beirut?
item.description: He is also wanted for his role in a 1983 attack in Beirut that killed some 300 American and French soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Rewards for Justice, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo of Fuad Shukr, from a wanted poster released by the U.S. State Department.

item.title: How the U.S. Reclaimed Its Golden Crown in Women’s Gymnastics Final
item.description: The United States pulled away, winning ahead of Italy, which won its first team medal since 1928, and Brazil, which claimed its first team medal ever.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Chang W. Lee, Gabriela Bhaskar and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Southport Mourns 3 Stabbing Victims: ‘Just Little Girls Who Wanted to Dance’
item.description: A day after a knife attack that killed three children, the community of Southport was grappling with the violence that had visited the town.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Adam Vaughan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Leaving tributes on Tuesday at the scene of a stabbing attack in Southport, England. Three children died from their injuries.

item.title: Here’s the latest on the attack in Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad

item.title: After Biden’s Withdrawal, Some Want Their Aged Leaders to Follow His Lead
item.description: Most of the world’s oldest leaders — in their 80s and even one in his 90s — are in Africa, which happens to have the youngest population of any continent.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Paul Biya of Cameroon with his wife, Chantal Biya, in Yaoundé, the capital, in May. At 91, Mr. Biya is the world’s oldest leader.

item.title: Israel’s Military Has Shrunk Gaza’s Humanitarian Zone by a Fifth
item.description: Israel’s military has redrawn the zone’s borders twice, accusing Hamas of using it to regroup and launch missiles.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Mohammed Salem/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinians returned to the eastern side of Khan Younis in Gaza on Tuesday after Israeli forces pulled out of the area.

item.title: Venezuelan Political Leaders Call for Rallies Over Contested Election Results
item.description: The fatal violence comes as both President Nicolás Maduro and the opposition claimed victory in the presidential election. More protests were taking place on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends of Anthony Garcia, 20, at his grave in Caracas on Tuesday. Mr. Garcia was shot and killed on Monday while driving near a protest in El Valle, a working-class neighborhood in the capital.

item.title: France Backs Morocco’s Western Sahara Plan in Letter to King
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron said Paris would support Morocco’s plan, which gives the disputed territory limited autonomy but keeps it under Moroccan control.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Christophe Ena/Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters with the Moroccan flag in Paris in 2016. France had previously argued that Morocco’s plan for autonomy for Western Sahara was a “serious and credible” basis for discussion, but not the only one.

item.title: Bangladesh Dragnet Sweeps Up Thousands in Protest Crackdown
item.description: Charges include vandalism, arson, theft, trespassing and damage to state property. A rights group called it a witch hunt, following an initial crackdown during which more than 200 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Monirul Alam/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A suspect arrested in connection with the violence during student protests being escorted to the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate Court in Dhaka this week.

item.title: Hong Kong Taunts Italy With Pineapple Pizza After Olympics Fencing Win
item.description: After a fencer from Hong Kong beat an Italian for a gold medal, Pizza Hut’s offer of free pineapple toppings in Hong Kong was the city’s second jab at Italy.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Maye-E Wong/Reuters
item.media:description: Cheung Ka Long of Hong Kong celebrated after winning the gold medal bout against Filippo Macchi of Italy, in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Ramps Up Mobilization of Troops
item.description: Large numbers of recruits will arrive at the front in the coming weeks, soldiers and military analysts said, but some are poorly trained or out of shape.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Training in June. Personnel shortages have been one of Ukraine’s biggest problems on the battlefield for the past year.

item.title: Why Is China Pressuring the Philippines in the South China Sea?
item.description: China claims most of the strategic waterway and is trying to push out neighbors like the Philippines. Any deadly mistake could risk war.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese militia and Coast Guard vessels chasing a Philippine Coast Guard ship in the South China Sea last year.

item.title: Southport Stabbing: What We Know About the Suspect, Victims and Riot
item.description: Three children died and five were in critical condition after the attack at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class on Monday. On Tuesday, rioters whom the police believe are far-right supporters injured dozens of officers.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: James Speakman/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers securing the area after a knife attack that killed three children in Southport, England, on Monday.

item.title: Who Are the Druse in the Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights?
item.description: There are more than one million Druse, a religious group with roots in the 11th century, across the Middle East. There are about 150,000 Druse in northern Israel and the Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Druse residents gathering at the site of a rocket strike in Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights. There are more than a million Druse across the Middle East, mostly in Syria and Lebanon.
